citation:Description.dsDescription:Text: The purpose of this study is to look at how different types of diets (low carbohydrate or low fat) affect the level of hormones in blood, metabolism, and appetite in children with PWS. The results from this study will provide information that can be used to design evidence-based diet plans for children with PWS.

ore:describes.socialscience:Collection Mode: Face-to-face interview; Self-administered questionnaire: Paper; Self-administered writings and/or diaries; Physical measurements and tests
ore:describes.Title: Evidence-Based Approach to Dietary Management of Prader-Willi Syndrome (PWS)
ore:describes.Subject: Medicine, Health and Life Sciences
ore:describes.socialscience:Characteristics of Data Co: Suppression of ghrelin will be measured at 10 hour fast following completion of dietary intervention. Fasting labs will be obtained immediately following dietary intervention. These labs will include total and active ghrelin. Changes in subjective hunger will be assessed by an appetite and hyperphagia questionnaire validated for PWS children. Analysis of improvements in insulin sensitivity and inflammatory cytokine profile will include measurements of adiponectin, GLP-1, glucose, insulin, AST, ALT, insulin sensitivity and a detailed profile ('metabolomics') of amino acids, fatty acids, acylcarnitines, and adipocytokines on the day prior to and immediately following dietary intervention. Changes in satiety, improvements in insulin sensitivity, and improvement in inflammatory cytokine profile are measured during the 72 hour dietary intervention.
ore:describes.socialscience:Universe: Children aged 5 years to 17 years with a diagnosis of Prader Willi syndrome confirmed by chromosome analysis.
ore:describes.socialscience:Frequency: Data is collected daily over the four days of the clinical visit.
ore:describes.Kind of Data: Biosamples; Questionnaire data; Interview data; Clinical data; Anthropometric data
ore:describes.socialscience:Sampling Procedure: 13 study participants will be recruited through convenience sample.
ore:describes.schema:name: Evidence-Based Approach to Dietary Management of Prader-Willi Syndrome (PWS)
ore:describes.dvcore:restrictions: Given the small population size and risk of reidentification, no direct access will be provided to the data.
ore:describes.dvcore:conditions: Access to the data is limited to selected members of the research team.

dvcore:fileTermsOfAccess.dvcore:availabilityStatus: Data is not available because the study is still recruiting.

ore:describes.schema:includedInDataCatalog: Women and Children's Health Research Institute (WCHRI)
